results.title: Between cultures
results.creator_credit: Daryl Wayland, Country Education Project and David Zweck
results.brief_description: Peter Couchman explores human relationships between cultures and the struggle to obtain cultural identity. The theme is gradually unfolded through interviews with Morag Loh, co-author of “The Immigrants” and discussion with people personally involved with the struggle between cultures.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Daryl Wayland, Country Education Project and David Zweck

results.title: Between Brecht and Beckett
results.creator_credit: Jamie Muir, WNET (Television station : New York, N.Y.) and BBC
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “Changing stages”.
Fifth episode in the six-part series “Changing stages”, written and presented by Richard Eyre, about the history of theatre in the 20th century. The aftermath of WW II influenced the direction of theatre and allowed a whole new generation of playwrights the freedom to express their anger, their political allegiance, social realism and an attitude that you could do or say what you want on stage - theatre became the instrument of social change. However, it was first German dramatist and poet, Bertolt Brecht (1898-1956), then Irish born Samuel Beckett (1906-1989) who inspired the 1960s and 70s generation of playwrights. Brecht, a communist, was known as a “theorist about theatre” who challenged the traditional values of theatre creating experimental and revolutionary works around his theory of alienation, promoting a style of acting and staging that created a distancing effect. Samuel Beckett was the man of evocative language, his plays often shrouded in despair and bleakness, combined with a lacing of caustic humor and left-wing politics. Richard Eyre presents indepth biographical backgrounds of each of these playwrights, including excerpts from their plays “The Resistible rise of Arturo Ui” and “Galileo” (Brecht), and “Waiting for Godot” (Beckett). Also features playwrights Edward Bond, Harold Pinter, Caryl Churchill, David Hare, Alan Bennett, Tom Stoppard and others along with film clips, excerpts and interviews. In addition, the program provides an historical overview of Britain during the 60s and 70s, the political and sexual freedom and the social mores of a society in the throes of a revolution - in fact, the whole world seemed to be in a state of protest in 1968. Follows through to the 1970s, to 1979 and the beginning of Thatcherism in Britain. Contains interviews with actors, playwrights and directors including John McGrath, Peter Brook, Tony Kushner, Billie Whitelaw. Some footage in b&w. For more information see www.pbs.org/wnet/changingstages.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jamie Muir, WNET (Television station : New York, N.Y.) and BBC

results.title: Betty: a shop steward
results.creator_credit: Tom Manefield, Linda Blagg and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Our multicultural society”.
Betty, from a Scottish working-class background, is a shop steward who plays a strong role in improving conditions at the factory in which she works. Intended to look critically and personally at the stereotype of the “pommy troublemaker” unionist, the film also raises other questions about working women.

results.title: Betty Viazim. - Short version.
results.creator_credit: Elizabeth Knight, Film Australia and Daro Gunzburg
results.brief_description: Looks at the life and work of Betty Viazim a milliner who began her apprenticeship at thirteen in 1922 in Sydney. During her career she worked for theatre and film and her creations have featured in productions by the Australian Ballet and others. Also provides a glimpse of Australian working life during the 1920s, 1930s and 1940s.

results.title: Betty Pounder
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Dance: Videos of Australian dancers and choreographers”.
As a dancer, ballet mistress, choreographer and director, Betty Pounder’s name is synonymous with musical theatre in Australia. She recalls the diverse and vital theatre scene in the heyday of “J.C. Williamson’s” and gives an insight into the working lives of musical performers. Pounder was responsible for presenting the work of America’s greatest choreographers and was associated with the Australian productions of landmark musicals such as “The Pyjama Game”, “Man of La Mancha”, “Camelot” and “My Fair Lady”. Pounder discusses the impact of developments in technique and training on dance in Australia and comments on current trends in musical theatre. Research and interview by James Murdoch.

results.title: Betty Cuthbert
results.creator_credit: Kathy Mueller, Pamela Vanneck, Ron Saunders, Coote and Carroll and Roadshow Television
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Willesee’s Australians”.
This moving drama series on important figures from Australia’s past brings history to life. Betty Cuthbert, the “Golden Girl”, held a very special place in the affections of the sporting world because of her immense courage, optimism and innate modesty. Betty competed in 3 Olympic Games during her 13 year career as the world’s greatest female runner.

results.title: Betty blue = 37.2 Le Matin (Director's cut)
results.creator_credit: Volker Lemke, Constellation Productions, Cargo Films and Jean-Jacques Beineix
results.brief_description: A contemporary tale of ‘amour fou’ based on the novel by Phillipe Djian, “Betty blue” is the story of Zorg (Jean-Hugues Anglade) who at 31 has accepted a certain measure of resignation, and the beautiful, passionate nineteen year old Betty (Beatrice Dalle), who dramatically enters his life and proceeds to dismantle his complacency with her volatile, urgent nature. Betty and Zorg’s life together is dominated by Betty’s fearless embracing of whatever emotion or new circumstance presents itself. This propels them both into a series of events and encounters by turns comic and poignant. Betty’s restlessness and her ever-worsening mental illness finds a focus in Zorg. She decides he is a brilliant writer and she sets about despatching his diaries to potential publishers. In the face of disappointment, however, Betty’s increasingly extreme reactions begin to reveal an instinct for self-destruction that Zorg is helpless to subdue. French language with English subtitles.

results.title: Better work methods. Pt. 5
results.brief_description: Illustrates original and then improved methods for (i) opening shipping cartons for breakfast cereal; (ii) trimming asparagus; (iii) folding packing papers; (iv) arranging height of work benches; (v) arranging seating accommodation for operatives. Silent film with English intertitles.
